paper_abstract: Given a set of axis-parallel rectangles in the plane, finding a maximum independent set (), a maximum weighted independent set (), and a minimum hitting set (), are basic problems in computational geometry and combinatorics. They have attracted significant attention since the sixties, when Wegner conjectured that the duality gap, equal to the ratio between the size of and the size of , is always bounded by a universal constant. An interesting case is when there exists a diagonal line that intersects each of the given rectangles. Indeed, Chepoi and Felsner recently gave a 6-approximation algorithm for in this setting, and showed that the duality gap is between 3/2 and 6. We consider the same setting and improve upon these results. First, we derive an -time algorithm for the when, in addition, every pair of intersecting rectangles have a common point below the diagonal. This improves and extends a classic result of Lubiw, and gives a 2-approximation algorithm for . Second, we show that is NP-hard. Finally, we prove that the duality gap is between 2 and 4. The upper bound, which implies a 4-approximation algorithm for , follows from simple combinatorial arguments, whereas the lower bound represents the best known lower bound on the duality gap, even in the general setting of the rectangles.
paper_title: Independent and Hitting Sets of Rectangles Intersecting a Diagonal Line: Algorithms and Complexity
